Summary: The proposal aims to develop scalable and robust probabilistic inference techniques by combining Bayesian methods with deep learning. It addresses limitations in current VI and MCMC methods, proposing adaptive variational families, hybrid MCMC-VI, and uncertainty-aware deep architectures. The experiment plan includes synthetic data, high-dimensional problems, large-scale tasks, and real-world applications.
Weaknesses: Lacks depth in addressing potential technical challenges, especially computational overhead and integration complexity.
Limited discussion on trade-offs between expressiveness and tractability.
Validation plan could be more explicit about baseline comparisons and failure modes.
Questions: How will the computational overhead of hybrid MCMC-VI methods be managed?
What are the specific trade-offs between expressiveness and tractability in the proposed normalizing flows?
How will the proposed methods compare to state-of-the-art baselines in terms of computational efficiency and accuracy?
What specific strategies will be employed to ensure seamless integration of uncertainty-aware architectures into existing deep learning frameworks?
Are there any theoretical guarantees for the convergence of the proposed hybrid methods?
Limitations: Potential computational overhead of hybrid methods.
Trade-offs between expressiveness and tractability in normalizing flows.
Complexity in integrating probabilistic inference with deep learning architectures.
